tit.cmt: 原文に近いように元に戻しました。

sen.j: 神明造（しんめいづくり）は、日本の神社建築の1つである。
sen.e: The Shinmei-zukuri style is a style of shrine buildings in Japan.
The shinmei-zukuri style is a style of shrine buildings in Japan.
The shinmei-zukuri style is a style of shrine buildings in Japan.

sen.j: 伊勢神宮に代表される神明造は、出雲大社に代表される大社造や住吉大社に代表される住吉造と共に、もっとも古い神社建築様式とされる。
sen.e: It is said that the shinmei-zukuri style, typically the style of the Ise-jingu Shrine building, is one of the oldest styles of shrine architecture, together with the taisha-zukuri style, typically the style of the Izumo-taisha shrine building, and the Sumiyoshi-zukuri style, typically the style of Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine building.

It is said that the shinmei-zukuri style, represented by the Ise-jingu Shrine building, is one of the oldest styles of shrine architecture, together with the taisha-zukuri style, represented by the Izumo-taisha shrine building, and the Sumiyoshi-zukuri style, represented by the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine building.

It is said that the shinmei-zukuri style, represented by the Ise-jingu Shrine building, is one of the oldest styles of shrine architecture, together with the taisha-zukuri style, represented by the Izumo-taisha shrine building, and the Sumiyoshi-zukuri style, represented by the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine building.

sen.j: 大社造が正方形に近い宮殿を模したものと考えられ、住吉造が大嘗祭の建物に近似している。
sen.e: It is considered that the tasisha-zukuri style imitated palaces that had nearly square shapes, and the sumiyosi-zukuri style is close to the style of the building where Daijosai (first ceremonial offering of rice by newly-enthroned Emperor) is held.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is considered that the taisha-zukuri style imitated palaces that had nearly square shapes, and the sumiyoshi-zukuri style is close to the style of the building where the Daijosai (first ceremonial offering of rice by newly-enthroned Emperor) is held.

It is considered that the taisha-zukuri style imitated palaces that had nearly square shapes, and the sumiyoshi-zukuri style is close to the style of the building where the Daijosai (first ceremonial offering of rice by newly-enthroned Emperor) is held.

sen.j: しかしながら、神明造は奥行きより幅が大きく、高床式倉庫から発展し穀物の代わりに神宝を納めるように変化したと考えられている。
sen.e: However, it is considered that the shinmei-zukuri style, with its width longer than its depth, developed from takayukashiki-soko (warehouses on stilts) and changed so that the building became more fitted for keeping shinpo (sacred treasures) rather than storing grain.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, it is believed that the shinmei-zukuri style, with its width longer than its depth, developed from takayukashiki-soko (warehouses on stilts) and changed so that the building became more used for keeping shinpo (sacred treasures) than storing grain.

However, it is believed that the shinmei-zukuri style, with its width longer than its depth, developed from takayukashiki-soko (warehouses on stilts) and changed so that the building became more used for keeping shinpo (sacred treasures) than storing grain.

sen.j: なお、伊勢の神宮の皇大神宮・豊受大神宮両宮の正殿（本殿）の様式は、他社においてこれと完全に同じくするのを懼れ憚って採用していない。
sen.e: The style of each main hall of the two shrines of Kotai-jingu Shrine and Toyouke Dai-jingu Shrine in Ise has not been used in any other shrines, because it has been considered that it should be hesitated to use the entirely same style.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The style of each main hall of the two shrines of Kotai-jingu Shrine and Toyouke Dai-jingu Shrine in Ise has not been used in any other shrines, because of concerns surrounding using the exact same style.

The style of each main hall of the two shrines of Kotai-jingu Shrine and Toyouke Dai-jingu Shrine in Ise has not been used in any other shrines, because of concerns surrounding using the exact same style.

sen.j: このため、特別に唯一神明造（ゆいいつしんめいづくり）と呼ぶ。
sen.e: Therefore, this style of these halls is called the yuitsu-shinmei-zukuri style (literally, the only one shinmei-zukuri style) in particular.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, the style of these halls is called yuitsu-shinmei-zukuri style (literally, the sole shinmei-zukuri style) in particular.
Therefore, the style of these halls is called yuiitsu-shinmei-zukuri style (literally, the sole shinmei-zukuri style) in particular.

sen.j: 神明造の構造は、掘建柱・切妻造・平入である。
sen.e: The shinmei-zukuri style uses hottate bashira (earthfast posts), the kirizuma-zukuri style (an architectural style with a gabled roof) and hira-iri (the style of buildings which have the entrance on the long side of the buildings).

The shinmei-zukuri style uses hottate bashira (earthfast posts), has a kirizuma-zukuri style roof (an architectural style with a gabled roof) and hira-iri (the style of buildings which have the entrance on the long side of the buildings).

The shinmei-zukuri style uses hottate bashira (earthfast posts), has a kirizuma-zukuri style roof (an architectural style with a gabled roof) and hira-iri (the style of buildings which have the entrance on the long side of the buildings).

sen.j: 円柱の柱や鰹木を除き、ほぼ全てが平面的に加工され直線的な外観となる。
sen.e: Except the cylindrical pillars and Katsuogi (ornamental logs arranged orthogonal to the ridge of a Shinto shrine), the external view is straight, being processed flatly, in almost all cases.

Except the cylindrical pillars and Katsuogi (ornamental logs arranged perpendicular to the ridge of a Shinto shrine), the external view is almost completely made up of straight edges due to its flat construction.

Except the cylindrical pillars and Katsuogi (ornamental logs arranged perpendicular to the ridge of a Shinto shrine), the external view is almost completely made up of straight edges due to its flat construction.

sen.j: この点で、優美な曲線が与えられる大社造と大きく異なる。
sen.e: This provides a big difference from the taisha-zukuri style that is provided with graceful curves.
This is in contrast to taisha-zukuri style which has graceful curves.
This is in contrast to taisha-zukuri style which has graceful curves.

sen.j: 狭義では萱葺（かやぶき）に限るが、一般には板葺や銅葺を含める。
sen.e: The roof is limited to thatch in the narrow sense, but generally includes shingle roofs and copper roofs as well
The roof is limited to thatch in most cases, but can also include shingle roofs and copper roofs.
The roof is limited to thatch in most cases, but can also include shingle roofs and copper roofs.

sen.j: 伊勢神宮の摂社・末社・所管社のほぼすべては板葺であり、熱田神宮は銅葺である。
sen.e: Shingle roofs are used in almost all of the sessha (auxiliary shrine (dedicated to a deity close-related to that of a main shrine)), subordinate shrines and the other minor shrines of Ise-jingu Shrine, and Atsuta-jingu Shrine uses a copper roof.

Shingle roofs are used in almost all of the sessha (auxiliary shrines dedicated to a deity connected to that of the main shrine), subordinate shrines and the other minor shrines of Ise-jingu Shrine, and Atsuta-jingu Shrine has a copper roof.

Shingle roofs are used in almost all of the sessha (auxiliary shrines dedicated to a deity connected to that of the main shrine), subordinate shrines and the other minor shrines of Ise-jingu Shrine, and Atsuta-jingu Shrine has a copper roof.

sen.j: 日本に仏教が伝来し、普及したころ神道では寺院建築を瓦屋根と呼んだ。
sen.e: When Buddhism was brought to Japan and became worshiped widely, temple buildings were called Kawara-yane (tiled roofs).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When Buddhism was brought to Japan and came to be practiced widely, temple buildings were called Kawara-yane (tiled roofs).
When Buddhism was brought to Japan and came to be practiced widely, temple buildings were called Kawara-yane (tiled roofs).

sen.j: そのことから、神社建築においては瓦屋根は異例である。
sen.e: Therefore, tiled roofs are rarely used in shrine buildings.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: For this reason tiled roofs are rarely used in shrine buildings.
For this reason tiled roofs are rarely used in shrine buildings.

sen.j: 屋根に耐久性の低い萱や板を使うため、屋根の勾配をきつくし、雨や雪が流れ落ちやすくする必要がある。
sen.e: Because less endurable thatch or shingles are used for the roof, the slope of the roof is made steep so that rain and snow drops along the roof more easily.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Because less endurable thatch or shingles are used for the roof, the angle of the roof is made steep so that rain and snow falls down the roof more easily.
Because less endurable thatch or shingles are used for the roof, the angle of the roof is made steep so that rain and snow falls down the roof more easily.

sen.j: 切妻であるため軒出も大きく作る必要がある。
sen.e: It is also necessary to make the eaves longer, because a kirizuma-style roof is used.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is also necessary to make the eaves longer, because a kirizuma-style roof is used.
It is also necessary to make the eaves longer, because a kirizuma-style roof is used.

sen.j: 屋根の頂上部は板で覆い、鰹木（かつおぎ）で補強される。
sen.e: The top part of the roof is covered with boards, and are reinforced with Katsuogi.
The top part of the roof is covered with boards, and is reinforced with Katsuogi.
The top part of the roof is covered with boards, and is reinforced with Katsuogi.

sen.j: 屋根を支える側面の破風（はふ）は継手でとどまらず、先端が飛び出し千木（ちぎ）となる。
sen.e: The bargeboards supporting the roof are not terminated at the connection part and protrude, becoming chigi.
The gables supporting the roof do not terminate where they meet, but protrude, forming chigi.
The gables supporting the roof do not terminate where they meet, but protrude, forming chigi.

sen.j: 千木と鰹木には、金銅製などの装飾金具が取り付けられ、耐候性を高められることがある。
sen.e: Decorative metal fittings are sometimes attached to Chigi and Kastsuogi to enhance their resistance to weather.
Decorative metal fittings are sometimes attached to Chigi and Kastsuogi to enhance their resistance to weather.
Decorative metal fittings are sometimes attached to Chigi and Kastsuogi to enhance their resistance to weather.

sen.j: 千木と鰹木に関しては千木・鰹木参照のこと。
sen.e: For Chigi and Kastsuogi, refer to Chigi and Katsuogi.
For Chigi and Kastsuogi, refer to Chigi and Katsuogi.
For Chigi and Kastsuogi, refer to Chigi and Katsuogi.

sen.j: 柱
sen.e: The pillars
The pillars
The pillars

sen.j: 神明造は基本的に左右対称で、左右方向には偶数本の柱が配される。
sen.e: The shinmei-zukuri style building is basically symmetric horizontally, with an even number of pillars provided on either side.
The shinmei-zukuri style building is basically horizontally symmetrical, with an even number of pillars on either side.
The shinmei-zukuri style building is basically horizontally symmetrical, with an even number of pillars on either side.

sen.j: 柱と地面の間には礎石も土台も与えらず、掘立柱となる。
sen.e: The pillars are earthfast, and neither base stones nor mud bases are provided between those pillars and the ground.
The pillars are earthfast, and neither base stones nor mud bases are used between the pillars and the surface of the ground.
The pillars are earthfast, and neither base stones nor mud bases are used between the pillars and the surface of the ground.

sen.j: 側面中央の、壁面より外側に飛び出し棟へ達する柱を棟持柱（むなもちばしら）と呼ぶ。
sen.e: The pillar that is placed at the center of each side, a little outside of the wall, and reaches the ridge is called Munamochi-bashira (literally, a ridge-supporting pillar).
The pillars at the center of each side, a little outside of the wall, and reaching the ridge are called Munamochi-bashira (literally, ridge-supporting pillar).
The pillars at the center of each side, a little outside of the wall, and reaching the ridge are called Munamochi-bashira (literally, ridge-supporting pillar).

sen.j: 棟持柱は通常太く、強度のある用材が用いられるが、構造上では強度にはあまり寄与しない。
sen.e: A strong thick wood is ordinarily used for the Munamochi-bashira, but this pillar contributes little to the strength of the building.
Strong thick wood is usually used for the Munamochi-bashira, but this pillar actually contributes little to the strength of the building.
Strong thick wood is usually used for the Munamochi-bashira, but this pillar actually contributes little to the strength of the building.

sen.j: 社殿の中央には心の御柱（しんのみはしら）が配されるが、これも強度には寄与しない。
sen.e: A pillar called Shinnomihasira is provided at the center of the shrine building, but this pillar contributes little to the strength of the building either.
A pillar called Shinnomihashira is located at the center of the shrine building, but this pillar contributes little to the strength of the building either.
A pillar called Shinnomihashira is located at the center of the shrine building, but this pillar contributes little to the strength of the building either.

sen.j: 壁
sen.e: The walls
The walls
The walls

sen.j: 神明造の壁は、十分な強度を持つ板材が用いられる。
sen.e: Boards with a sufficient strength are used for walls of shinmei-zukuri style buildings.
Only boards of a sufficient strength are used for the walls of shinmei-zukuri style buildings.
Only boards of a sufficient strength are used for the walls of shinmei-zukuri style buildings.

sen.j: 正面中央の1か所のみに観音開きの御扉（おとびら）による開口部が設けられる。
sen.e: Only one opening of hinged double doors, called Otobira, is provided at the center of the front side.
There is a single opening with hinged double doors, called Otobira, at the center of the front side.
There is a single opening with hinged double doors, called Otobira, at the center of the front side.

sen.j: 御扉は通常1枚板が用いられるため、大規模な社殿では相当の古木が必要とされる。
sen.e: Otobira is ordinarily cut directly out of a tree, and therefore, a rather old big tree is required for a large-scale shrine building.
The Otobira is usually cut directly from a tree, and therefore a tree of considerable size is required for a large-scale shrine building.
The Otobira is usually cut directly from a tree, and therefore an old tree of considerable size is required for a large-scale shrine building.
sen.cmt: 「古木」ですので、oldを入れました。

sen.j: 皇大神宮正殿の場合は樹齢400年以上のヒノキが必要になるという。
sen.e: It is said that a 400-year or older (Japanese) cypress is necessary for the main hall of Kotai-jingu Shrine.
It is said that a Japanese cypress of 400 years or more would be necessary for the main hall of Kotai-jingu Shrine.
It is said that a Japanese cypress of 400 years or more would be necessary for the main hall of Kotai-jingu Shrine.

sen.j: 床
sen.e: The floors
The floors
The floors

sen.j: 神明造では通風性を重視した床が高い構造で、高床式倉庫の名残であると考えられている。
sen.e: Floors raised from ground are used for shinmei-zukuri buildings, placing importance on ventilation, and this is considered a vestige of takayukashiki-soko (warehouse on stilts).
Shinmei-zukuri buildings have floors raised from the ground, with importance placed on ventilation, and this is considered to be a vestige of the design of takayukashiki-soko (warehouse on stilts).
Shinmei-zukuri buildings have floors raised from the ground, with importance placed on ventilation, and this is considered to be a vestige of the design of takayukashiki-soko (warehouse on stilts).

sen.j: このため相当長い階段が必要になる。
sen.e: Therefore, use of a rather long stair becomes necessary.
Accordingly, these building usually have a comparatively long set of steps.
Accordingly, these building usually have a comparatively long set of steps.

sen.j: 歴史は古く、記録に残っていないため定かでない。
sen.e: The history started at ancient times, but is unclear because no record remains.
The history of this architectural style is long, but its exact beginnings are unknown.
The history of this architectural style is long, but its exact beginnings are unknown.

sen.j: 弥生時代の遺跡の柱の遺構が神明造の柱の配置に似ているため、弥生時代の高床式倉庫が発展したものと考えられている。
sen.e: The pillar layout of remains in the Yayoi Period is similar that of the shinmei-zukuri style buildings, and therefore, it is considered that the shinmei-zukuri style developed from takayukashiki-soko.

The layout of pillars in remains from the Yayoi Period is similar to that of the shinmei-zukuri style buildings, and so it is considered that the shinmei-zukuri style developed out of takayukashiki-soko.

The layout of pillars in remains from the Yayoi Period is similar to that of the shinmei-zukuri style buildings, and so it is considered that the shinmei-zukuri style developed out of takayukashiki-soko in this period.

sen.j: 神明造の社殿は、江戸時代以前は伊勢神宮と、信濃国（現在の長野県）の神宮の所領とされた仁科神明宮、丹後国（現在の京都府）の籠神社など少数であった。
sen.e: In the Edo period and before it, only a few shrines, including the following, were built in the shinmei-zukuri style: Ise-jingu Shrine, Nishina-shinmeigu Shrine, which was under control of a Shinto priest of Shinano Province (present Nagano City), and Kono-jinja Shrine in Tango Province (present Kyoto Prefecture).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処神宮： ”しんかん（神主）”として訳してあります。
sen.e: In the Edo Period and before, only a few shrines, including the following, were built in the shinmei-zukuri style: Ise-jingu Shrine, Nishina-shinmeigu Shrine, which was under the control of a Shinto priest of Shinano Province (present day Nagano City), and Kono-jinja Shrine in Tango Province (present day Kyoto Prefecture).

In the Edo Period and before, only a few shrines, including the following, were built in the shinmei-zukuri style: Ise-jingu Shrine, Nishina-shinmeigu Shrine, which was under the control of a Shinto priest of Shinano Province (present day Nagano Prefecture), and Kono-jinja Shrine in Tango Province (present day Kyoto Prefecture).

sen.j: しかし、明治以降は合祀などによる遷宮において神明造を採用することが流行し、神明造の社殿が増加した。
sen.e: However, in the Meiji period and later, the shinmei-zukuri style has been adopted widely in shrine buildings for installing a sacred symbol, for example, in enshrining another god together, increasing the number of shinmei-zukuri style shrine buildings.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, from the Meiji Period shinmei-zukuri style has been adopted widely for shrine buildings which contain sacred symbols, or in enshrining another god, thus increasing the number of shinmei-zukuri style shrine buildings.

However, from the Meiji Period shinmei-zukuri style has been adopted widely for shrine buildings in time of sengu (transfer of a deity to a new shrine building), due to, for example, enshrining multiple gods collectively, thus increasing the number of shinmei-zukuri style shrine buildings.

sen.j: 熱田神宮が神明造になったのも明治の遷宮からである。
sen.e: The Atsuta shrine building became the shinmei-zukuri style for the first time in sengu (transfer of a deity to a new shrine building) in the Meiji period.
The Atsuta shrine building was built in shinmei-zukuri style for the first time in the sengu (transfer of a deity to a new shrine building) in the Meiji Period.
The Atsuta shrine building was built in shinmei-zukuri style for the first time in the sengu in the Meiji Period.
sen.cmt: 遷宮の注釈は上のセルでしたので、ここでは省きました。
